It's always impressive when you see sci-fi films from the 50s and 60s that show TVs as widescreen -- often very close to today's 16:9 aspect ratio (e.g. "Fahrenheit 451" - 1966 - with its very large flat wide displays, and even small TVs in that aspect ratio. "2001: A Space Odyssey" -- 1968 -- is another obvious example).

Ironically, many later films and TV shows wanted to be more "authentic" and used actual CRT displays, meaning that they were virtually always in conventional 4:3 ratio and look hilariously dated for a story placed in the (sometimes far) future.

Sidenote: Shooting movie film in particular from a CRT was quite a trick in the earlier days, and various efforts were made to try avoid visual "hum bars" -- though they were never usually 100% successful. However, such shots (e.g. "The Manchurian Candidate" - 1962) do give a realistic sense of the time in these non-sci-fi films.

Since I brought up The Manchurian Candidate (and note I'm talking about the '62 version, not the completely forgettable recent remake), this is a very fine film, starring Frank Sinatra, Laurence Harvey, and Angela Lansbury (Lansbury in one of the most sinister and strange roles of her career, to be sure.)

The set piece of the film is a sequence near the beginning that involves transitioning between a Chinese brainwashing presentation and what appears to be the meeting of a women's garden club. This was shot in real time without any cuts, and is a marvel of stage and camera work. The screenplay was written by George Axelrod, who went on to write the screenplay for "Lord Love a Duck" (1966) -- an utterly different and bizarre kind of film that we will discuss in detail sometime in the future.

For now, "The Manchurian Candidate" is available for free (assume mostly U.S. only) on #YouTube Movies and TV. Highly recommended. But keep your card deck full of Queen of Diamonds nearby!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=R3ZiN3nU4zY

title: Crypto Mining. Be More Careful Than This!

last_post.content:
Dude got wrecked when his power bill jumped from 9¢ to 15¢ with no notice.
He mentions Ethereum, so he's aware that Proof of Stake coins exist. Yet the lessons he's learned from his experience? None of them include that he could stop mining. Stop wasting all that electricity burning all those fossil fuels.
It's amazing to me when obviously intelligent, self-aware, introspective people get stuck in a very specific strategy. "What's my most valuable asset?" he asks himself. "Knowledge," he concludes. OK, cool, if you're still going to crypto, stop mining, chase 1 of 100 other angles in crypto?
With music swelling behind him, he's doubling down on the mining grind.
Mining as religion.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0e9j7J1Y4lQ

As the topic du jour is the (recurrent) question of whether it is [legal | ethical] to "teach" #MachineLearning models on internet data, I'm reminded of my favorite "fun fact" about FEC campaign data. Data about your ($200+) political donations are public, but "cannot be sold or used for soliciting contributions [...] or for any commercial purpose."¹ Violators get caught because campaigns "salt" disclosures with fake data as misuse canaries.²

¹ https://www.fec.gov/updates/sale-or-use-contributor-information/
² https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SSVGrpjQX4o

The scariest climate science paper I've ever read?

At 1 degree centigrade of temperature rise, we can trigger 4 climate tipping points, at 1.5 degrees they are certain to trigger, and another 5 tipping points could also happen. Once they take over, we are powerless to stop them. Quite terrifying. Please wake up world!

Read more in /tipping-points
(https://) uncensorednews.us/tipping-points

https://www.youtube.com/embed/LxoyaCSWFGs

#climate #climatechange #climatecrisis #videos

How Close Are We to a Climate Change Tipping Point?

On the left, the head of the Potsdam Institute of Climatology tells us exactly the current state of the world. In the middle the head of the IPCC does not add much, but makes a few good points. You can skip him. And I quite skipped the opening NYT reporters comments.

Read more in /tipping-points

title: “Humanity is on thin ice”: IPCC releases 6th synthesis report on global climate change | FULL

last_post.content:
#IPCC What I heard from the lead author's today:

•We'll pass 1.5° in early 2030s
•Rest of 2020s is key
•Storm frequency / severity will continue to go up
•All projects should be climate solutions
•Financing is needed & a good financial investment
•To work, ideas need to be vetted by community partners
•We have good tools + science already
•Mitigation / adaptation are more possible now than ever.

#ClimateAction #ClimateChange
